Problem:
Consider the linear transformation in a vector space under the integral operator \\( T \\) defined by \\( T[f](x) = \\int_{0}^{x} e^{(x-t)^2} f(t) dt \\). The system's dynamics are influenced by an externally applied multiplicative function \\( g(t) = t^2+1 \\) at different times.

If the function \\( g(t) \\) is applied to an initial function \\( f(t) \\) in the definition of \\( T \\) at t = 0, and then the system evolves under \\( T \\) without further intervention, will the transformation \\( T[f](x) \\) at x = T be the same as if \\( f(t) \\) was directly transformed by \\( T \\) to x = T without applying \\( g(t) \\)?
Explanation: Applying \\( g(t) \\) to \\( f(t) \\) before transformation by \\( T \\) modifies the initial function from \\( f(t) \\) to \\( f(t)(t^2+1) \\). This initial modification changes the entire profile of integrals across the domain of \\( T \\), resulting in a different transformed function at x = T because the integrand and bounds depend on this new function.
